0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Venous varices: 0.5 to 2 mL (preferably 1 mL) IV into the vein intended for sclerosis; the 1% solution is used most often, with the 3% solution being reserved for larger varicosities; MAX single treatment, do not exceed 10 mL

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Acute cellulitis
  • Acute infections
  • Acute superficial thrombophlebitis
  • Allergic conditions
  • Bedridden patients
  • Huge superficial veins with wide open communications to deeper veins
  • Phlebitis migrans
  • Previous hypersensitivity reactions to the drug
  • Significant valvular or deep vein incompetence
  • Uncontrolled systemic diseases (diabetes, toxic hyperthyroidism, tuberculosis, asthma, neoplasm, sepsis, blood dyscrasias and acute respiratory or skin diseases)
  • Varicosities caused by abdominal and pelvic tumors unless the tumor has been removed

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Allergic reactions, including fatal anaphylaxis have been reported
  • Do not administer sclerotherapy if tests, such as the Trendelenburg and Perthes, and angiography show significant valvular or deep venous incompetence
  • Extravasation
  • Patients with underlying arterial diseases, such as peripheral arteriosclerosis or thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site ulcer, Urticaria
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea, Vomiting
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction, eg, asthma, hives, hayfever
  • Neurologic:Headache, Pain
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Deep venous thrombosis
  • Dermatologic:Necrosis, following extravasation, Skin necrosis, following extravasation
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, death reported
  • Respiratory:Pulmonary embolism

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Sodium tetradecyl sulfate, an anionic surfactant, is a sclerosing agent that produces inflammation of the intima and formation of a thrombus, which results in vein occlusion in the treatment of varicose veins. Subsequent fibrous tissue formation may lead in partial or complete vein obliteration.

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• symptomatic improvement
  • signs and symptoms of thrombosis
  • signs and symptoms of extravasation

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause injection site ulcer, nausea, vomiting, headache, or pain.
  • Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of deep venous thrombosis, skin necrosis, or pulmonary embolism.
  • Patient should monitor for and report extravasation during drug administration.
